Halide substitution was adopted to enhance the RT Li + conductivity in LiBH 4. A solid solution is formed by substituting BH 4 – with I –, Br –, and Cl –, stabilizing the hexagonal polymorph at RT.
10, 13, 14 Mixing other complex anions with LiBH 4 ( e.g., NH 2 – and NH 2–) leads to the formation of compounds with different structures, with enhanced ionic conductivity at RT.
15, 16 Recently, it was reported that partial dehydrogenation of LiBH 4 leads to different Li–B–H complexes with significantly higher Li-ion conductivity (∼2.7 × 10 –4 S cm –1 at 35 °C).
